Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I was kneeling in the back of the ambulance, methodically checking the first-aid kit. Gauze, bandages, epinephrine—each item had to be accounted for, nothing expired, nothing missing. My mind was focused, knowing that someone’s life could depend on this kit being perfect. Suddenly, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the online candidate forum for my district was starting. I’d promised myself I’d watch it live, ask questions, and stay informed. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to participate, to make my voice heard, especially with the election coming up. But as an ambulance driver, I couldn’t rush this check. If I missed something, it could cost a patient dearly. My hands hesitated over the supplies, my eyes flicking to the phone screen. The forum was streaming now, and I could already see the chat filling with questions. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one demanding my undivided attention for the sake of a stranger’s life, the other insisting I fulfill my civic duty. My heart pounded as I wrestled with which expectation to meet first.
